The reactor was a high enriched uranium-based water reactor. There were two cores: Core I and Core II. The "waste" from such a reactor (for both cores) would mostly be a minor concern now, 50 years later (as most of the radioactively hazardous materials have short half lives--the long-lived stuff, by definition of half life, releases small amounts of energy over a long period of time). The big issue would be the uranium, and some of the toxic heavy metals that were generated (since a reactor produces basically every element on the periodic table during operation). See the following for more info:
- https://youtu.be/1Ujx_pND9wg?t=1165 - declassified video on Camp Century, with time-code to the ~10 minutes showing the reactor
- https://www.osti.gov/biblio/4143582-specifications-fabrication-procedures-pm-core-ii-control-rod-fuel-elements - report on the design of the fuel control elements.
- https://www.osti.gov/biblio/4183716-specifications-fabrication-procedures-pm-core-ii-stationary-fuel-elements - report on the design of the other fuel elements.

We've seen release of material somewhat similar to this, and its impact, especially if it will be over 100 years after it was shut down before this is exposed, will be pretty minor. Nuclear "waste" isn't as scary or dangerous as people like to make it out to be.

Well the Cold War was no joke and Camp Century was no folly. The US Military explored many avenues of missile deployment- And rightfully (thankfully) so. The Soviet nuclear buildup was  a threat that had to be matched if an (uncomfortable) balance was to be maintained. The now decommissioned Minuteman silos never had to react, and served their purpose precisely.

This is what drives me bonkers about your average online edgelord climate denier. Scientists spend 4 years in undergrad, however many years they individually do on their post graduate work, then they come together in groups and spend literal decades doing experiments, collating new data, going over old data that itself took anywhere from minutes to centuries for other scientists (who themselves all had years of study and experiment under their belts) to gather.

But then Edgelord shows up and says, "the climate has always fluctuated, how is what is happening now any different? It's not, climate change is a leftist conspiracy to ignore biological sex!!1!!1!!" and now we are supposed to take what adds up to decades upon decades of research and synthesize it into a comment that someone with a screen name touting Pewdiepie can understand in less than two minutes.

That isn't how science works.

It is a pretty accurate example of hubris, however. Just because you can't understand it, you know, without having dedicated your entire life to understanding all the ins and outs and small nuances - doesn't make it fake. It makes it something YOU don't understand. That is why we have experts on each specific thing!!!
